title: Kathak
short_description: Characterized by intricate footwork and rapid pirouettes, this dance form narrates mythological tales through expression.
long_description:
Kathak is the major classical dance form of Northern India, deriving its name from the Sanskrit word 'Katha' which means story. The Kathakars were originally traveling bards who used dance and song to recount the great epics. Over time, it evolved in the Mughal courts, absorbing Persian influences which gave it a unique blend of Hindu and Muslim cultural elements.

Key features of Kathak include intricate footwork (tatkar), rapid pirouettes (chakkars), and a straight-legged stance. Unlike other Indian classical forms that use bent knees, Kathak is performed standing straight. The dance focuses heavily on rhythm and the interplay with the Tabla and Pakhawaj. It has three main Gharanas (schools): Lucknow, Jaipur, and Banaras, each emphasizing different aspects like expression or technical brilliance.

Kathak is mesmerizing for its dizzying spins and the delicate nuances of facial expression (abhinaya) used to depict thumris and ghazals.
costume_and_makeup: Costumes vary by religious influence. Hindu style involves a ghagra (long skirt), choli (blouse), and veil. Mughal style features a churidar-pyjama and an angarkha (frock-coat) with a cap. Both styles involve heavy ghungroos (bells) around the ankles, which are continuously manipulated to produce rhythms.

practical_info.audience_tips: Applaud generous 'sum' landings (where the beat cycle resolves). Listen for the intricate mathematical recitation (padhant).

teaching_workshop_details.booking_info: Inquire at Kathak Kendra or private schools in Delhi/Lucknow.
